items.fromString:
The [Seed job|https://jarl.internal.psicloud.de/job/idp/job/seed/] has a webhook configured, but the webhook trigger in the job is disabled. The job only runs when triggered automatically, which already lead to a configuration drift between the build job declared in our repo, and the actual configuration of that job.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* The Seed job runs after every merge to {{main}}.

items.fromString:
We currently have two jobs, only one of which, our [build job|https://jarl.internal.psicloud.de/job/idp/job/build/], was created by just declaring the job in our repository, and letting the [seed job|https://jarl.internal.psicloud.de/job/idp/job/seed/] pick it up. This is already pretty close to an IDP approach.

We should embrace the IDP approach ourselves as much as possible. Therefore, all jobs should be created this way. Currently, this only concerns the [WMS playground job|https://jarl.internal.psicloud.de/job/playground/job/psiwms-trunk-linux/] created for [https://int-log-psise.atlassian.net/browse/DEVOPS-374|https://int-log-psise.atlassian.net/browse/DEVOPS-374|smart-link].

The jobs are created via [Job DSL|https://plugins.jenkins.io/job-dsl/]. Jarl’s DSL capabilities can be discovered [here|https://jarl.internal.psicloud.de/plugin/job-dsl/api-viewer/index.html].

*Steps:*

* “Copy” the existing [BuildJob.groovy|https://odin.internal.psicloud.de/devops/idp/-/blob/075a424b1221fef471ab4b58c3addfb278b61cac/jenkins/build/BuildJob.groovy] to {{jenkins/wms/*}}
* Add a filter for feature branch names. Only specific branches should trigger a build
* Add Sparse Checkout to {{third-party/psiwms}}

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* All our Jenkins jobs, except for the Seed job, are created by the Seed job.

items.fromString:
The current pipeline only targets one specific node, DE02SR314, but it should target any agent that has the required capabilities to run the pipeline. We discussed to use a separate label for hosts that are able to run a docker container, e.g., {{agent-docker}}.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* The WMS build pipeline only requests a {{label 'agent-docker'}} agent to run the build container on.
* The [list of Jenkins agents|https://jarl.internal.psicloud.de/label/agent-docker/] declaring the {{agent-docker}} label contains at least one online node (any {{DE02SR35*}} should be fine), but does not contain any hosts with long-running build containers for projects.

* The job runs successfully on all the nodes that are labeled accordingly.

items.fromString:
Currently, one prepared database is used by the dockerized build job from [https://int-log-psise.atlassian.net/browse/DEVOPS-364|https://int-log-psise.atlassian.net/browse/DEVOPS-364|smart-link], but this way, we cannot run multiple build or even test configurations in parallel. Instead, we want to be able to spawn databases during the build process. They should be destroyed at the end of the job run.

[~accountid:712020:132f073d-71ff-434c-b3f3-41b81f95446f] should be consulted to be sure that we use the correct db image; current assumption is {{container-registry.oracle.com/database/free:latest}}.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* The WMS build pipeline only requests a {{label 'agent-docker'}} agent to run the build container on.
* An Oracle DB 23 image is used for short-lived db containers to speed up initialization.
* The [list of Jenkins agents|https://jarl.internal.psicloud.de/label/agent-docker/] declaring the {{agent-docker}} label contains at least one online node (any {{DE02SR35*}} should be fine), but does not contain any hosts with long-running build containers for projects.

items.fromString:
There a couple of issues with out pipeline currently:

# on nodes (not sure if this is true for all nodes) 314 and 315 jenkins agent working directory is set to /home/jenkins/agent directory with is in a root file system. So not cleaning workspaces could lead to host crash due to lack of free space in rood filesystem.

All those issues caused {{no space left}} error on node 314 which we are using for our IDP pipeline and node was unreachable for some time.
items.toString:
There a couple of issues with out pipeline currently:

# on nodes (not sure if this is true for all nodes) with a Jenkins label {{agent-docker}}, working directory is set to {{/home/jenkins/}} agent directory with is in a root file system. So not cleaning workspaces could lead to host crash due to lack of free space in rood filesystem.

All those issues caused {{no space left}} error on {{agent-docker}} nodes which we are using for our IDP pipeline and node was unreachable for some time.

Should really be done by the Ops team; [~accountid:712020:7e9f70be-a016-4601-b6a2-01fc2f6526b4] proposed to hand this task over to them. We agreed to open an INFRAINT ticket for that to make it a little bit more official.

*Steps:*

# Check for existence of a suitable alternative mount
# If none exists, create one
## in proxmox
## in lvm
## edit {{/etc/fstab}}
## reboot? {{mount -a}}?
# Modify {{/etc/systemd/system/jenkins-agent.service}} to point to the correct mount point
# Restart the service

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* Workspaces on {{agent-docker}} nodes are no longer created in the root file system.

items.fromString:
There a couple of issues with out pipeline currently:

# multibranch pipeline do not clean up workspaces for the branches that are already merges and branches are deleted (possibly this is Jenkins project configuration issue? )
# on nodes (not sure if this is true for all nodes) 314 and 315 jenkins agent working directory is set to /home/jenkins/agent directory with is in a root file system. So not cleaning workspaces could lead to host crash due to lack of free space in rood filesystem.
# pipelines do not clean up localy build artifacts. On jenkins nodes there are multiple docker images that are build by our pipeline that are not deleted and persist after each build.

All those issues caused `no space left` error on node 314 which we are using for our IDP pipeline and node was unreachable for some time.

items.toString:
[https://int-log-psise.atlassian.net/browse/DEVOPS-379|https://int-log-psise.atlassian.net/browse/DEVOPS-379|smart-link] only tracks the main branch of every repo in a Gitlab group. There are cases where you want to provision branch-specific resources, like a testing environment from certain feature branches.

Therefore, we should deploy from _every_ branch that declares a bunch of resources.

To keep resource consumption in check, we need to be able to restrict resources to only a subset of branches. For example, if we declare a Kubernetes cluster in the {{deploy}} folder on the main branch, every feature branch branched off the main branch would otherwise create its own Kubernetes cluster, which we definitely do not want. This can probably be achieved with the [SCM Provider Generator|https://argo-cd.readthedocs.io/en/stable/operator-manual/applicationset/Generators-SCM-Provider/], too, by passing {{branch: {{ .branch }}}} as an additional key-value pair for the Helm chart, see [here|https://argo-cd.readthedocs.io/en/stable/operator-manual/applicationset/Generators-SCM-Provider/#pass-additional-key-value-pairs-via-values-field]. The branch value can then be evaluated in the Helm chart to disable certain resources.

For resources that should only be provisioned for certain branches (“branch-specific resource”), filters have to be defined to specify those branches. A branch that matches those filters is a “matching branch”.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* When a branch-specific {{Pod}} is declared on matching branch, that {{Pod}} is deployed specifically for that branch (e.g. with a name or in a namespace containing the branch name).
* When a branch-specific {{Pod}} is added to a non-matching branch, that {{Pod}} is not deployed specifically for that branch.

items.fromString:
Instead of deploying one Argo CD {{Application}} per repo that is “registered” to our platform, we could instead add an {{ApplicationSet}} that tracks _all_ repos in a certain group on a Gitlab instance, e.g. using the [SCM Provider Generator|https://argo-cd.readthedocs.io/en/stable/operator-manual/applicationset/Generators-SCM-Provider/].

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* Creating a new repo in the {{devops}} group on Odin (and if necessary, adding the file {{deploy/Chart.yaml}} to it on the main branch) automatically deploys an {{Application}} in Argo CD.
* When a {{Pod}} definition is added to the {{deploy/templates}} folder of any repo in the {{devops}} group on Odin, a corresponding {{Pod}} is deployed.
items.toString:
Instead of deploying one Argo CD {{Application}} per repo that is “registered” to our platform, we could instead add an {{ApplicationSet}} that tracks _all_ repos in a certain group on a Gitlab instance, e.g. using the [SCM Provider Generator|https://argo-cd.readthedocs.io/en/stable/operator-manual/applicationset/Generators-SCM-Provider/].

*Steps:*

* Create a token with reading permissions to the {{DevOps}} [group|https://odin.internal.psicloud.de/devops]
* Add this token as a sealed secret to our repo
* Change the {{ApplicationSet}}’s generator to a GitLab SCM Provider generator that uses the token.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* Creating a new repo in the {{DevOps}} group on Odin (and if necessary, adding the file {{deploy/Chart.yaml}} to it on the main branch) automatically deploys an {{Application}} in Argo CD.
* When a {{Pod}} definition is added to the {{deploy/templates}} folder of any repo in the {{DevOps}} group on Odin, a corresponding {{Pod}} is deployed.

items.fromString:
We’ll probably *not* need the following configurations:

* S2
* MINI
* ECOM

[~accountid:712020:084d1dec-3e54-455b-a9d0-afd1f7ae5ce2] should be consulted if our selection of test configurations is really useful/correct.

{noformat}STANDORT=ECOM2
sto ${STANDORT}; SpuDbDat.pl -bY  -m W "#CleanConf"
sto ${STANDORT}; SpuDbWatch.pl -e CHECK
sto ${STANDORT}; tst \#build
sto ${STANDORT}; dadx
less test/${STANDORT,,}/_log/index.html{noformat}

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* Have a separate pipeline stage to run {{sputest}} for the following configurations:
** ECOM2
** SLS
** S1
* Technical measures make sure that different {{sputests}} run in parallel cannot conflict with one another, e.g. on the database level using different databases or schemas.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* There’s a {{Jenkinsfile}} in our repo that uses an {{agent docker}} to build WMS.
* There’s a job pointing to the {{Jenkinsfile}} that successfully builds a stable (possibly old) revision of {{trunk}}.

customfield_10020.name: DEVOPS Sprint 17
customfield_10020.goal: Run WMS pipeline on arbitrary Jenkins docker agent

items.fromString:
There a couple of issues with out pipeline currently:

# multibranch pipeline do not clean up workspaces for the branches that are already merges and branches are deleted (possibly this is Jenkins project configuration issue? )
# on nodes (not sure if this is true for all nodes) 314 and 315 jenkins agent working directory is set to /home/jenkins/agent directory with is in a root file system. So not cleaning workspaces could lead to host crash due to lack of free space in rood filesystem.
# pipelines do not clean up localy build artifacts. On jenkins nodes there are multiple docker images that are build by our pipeline that are not deleted and persist after each build.

All those issues caused `no space left` error on node 314 which we are using for our IDP pipeline and node was unreachable for some time.

items.fromString:
If we want to create another configuration from the template to a repository where this file already exists we get an error.

{{InputError: Committing the changes to feature/backstage-mr-aaa failed. Please check that none of the files created by the template already exists. GitbeakerRequestError: Bad Request}}`

How do we want to handle this?

First approach: The filename differs from the given server name.

Second approach: It is ok, that only one file is there?

Maybe another approach?

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* Needs discussion
items.toString:
If we want to create another configuration from the template to a repository where this file already exists we get an error.

{{InputError: Committing the changes to feature/backstage-mr-aaa failed. Please check that none of the files created by the template already exists. GitbeakerRequestError: Bad Request}}`

filename differs from the given server name, so it contains the name of the server in it

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* Each config file contains the name of the server in it.
* It is possible to create multiple WmsServerHost *in Backstage* if they have different server names

Implement custom triggers for the ArgoCD Notification Controller to enhance automated notifications for specific events during application lifecycle management. * After failed sync, back to succeed sync alert is sent to gitlab project.

items.fromString:
When a resource of type {{ServiceHost}} ([https://int-log-psise.atlassian.net/browse/DEVOPS-299|https://int-log-psise.atlassian.net/browse/DEVOPS-299|smart-link]) is deployed, a load-balanced instance group should be created for the team, consisting of a MIG, a corresponding backend service with health check, URL map, HTTP proxy and forwarding rule.

The implementation can be taken from the {{WmsServerHost}} implementation by replacing all the WMS specific parts with fields from the {{ServiceHost}} CRD, or by using sensible defaults.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* Deploying a {{ServiceHost}} resource results in the creation of all the load-balancing components listed above, and an instance template.
items.toString:
_I want load-balancing components to be set up for my team’s_ {{ServiceHost}} _resources._

When a resource of type {{ServiceHost}} ([https://int-log-psise.atlassian.net/browse/DEVOPS-299|https://int-log-psise.atlassian.net/browse/DEVOPS-299|smart-link]) is deployed, a load-balanced instance group should be created for the team, consisting of a MIG, a corresponding backend service with health check, URL map, HTTP proxy and forwarding rule.

The implementation can be taken from the {{WmsServerHost}} implementation by replacing all the WMS specific parts with fields from the {{ServiceHost}} CRD, or by using sensible defaults.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* Deploying a {{ServiceHost}} resource results in the creation of all the load-balancing components listed above, and an instance template.

* No errors occur during application build.
* Basic functionality of the "Home" plugin is confirmed.
* Forward necessary information to ticket Devops-298

items.fromString:
After [https://int-log-psise.atlassian.net/browse/DEVOPS-279|https://int-log-psise.atlassian.net/browse/DEVOPS-279|smart-link] the instance will get a new IP each time it is changed. Therefore, we need a way to route the traffic so that there is only one IP for the end user to reach.

For this we need an internal load balancer. (regional or cross-region?)

Here is a Terraform example, although we will do it with Crossplane: [Terraform examples for a regional internal Application Load Balancer  |  Load Balancing  |  Google Cloud|https://cloud.google.com/load-balancing/docs/l7-internal/int-https-lb-tf-examples]

So we need:

* Backend Service
* Health-Check
* URL Map
* (Target) Http Proxy
* Forwarding Rule
* Maybe more?

For some of these, there are already some tests in our [IDP Playground|https://gitlab.com/tbenning/idp-playground]. I would recommend to test things, first create them in the playground.

Additionally, all Crossplane resources should be in the compute-provider. You can find them here: [upbound/provider-gcp-compute@v1.11.1 | Upbound Marketplace|https://marketplace.upbound.io/providers/upbound/provider-gcp-compute/v1.11.1]

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* Implement a load balancer to distribute traffic across the VMs in the Managed Instance Groups
* Configure health checks to ensure traffic is directed only to healthy instances during the rolling update process.

items.toString: This issue is prerequisite for DEVOPS-280

items.fromString:
As an Ops i want to have automatic rolling updates, so that there is no downtime of a service.

For this we need Managed Instance Groups (MIGs) and InstanceTemplates. Both are already tested in our IDP-Playground. But now we need them as a CompositeResource, so that Ops have only define minimal config.

It is *NOT* part of this ticket to reach the instance via the same url/ip.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* MIG and InstanceTemplate is a XRD and Composition
* In the Playground is only a claim for testing
* Changing e.g. the MachineType will automic lead to an new Instance
items.toString:
As an Ops i want to have automatic rolling updates, so that there is no downtime of a service.

For this we need Managed Instance Groups (MIGs) and InstanceTemplates. Both are already tested in our IDP-Playground. But now we need them as a CompositeResource, so that Ops have only define minimal config.

It is *NOT* part of this ticket to reach the instance via the same url/ip.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* MIG and InstanceTemplate is a XRD and Composition
* There should be one new instance up before deleting the old one so that there is up to no downtime
* In the Playground is only a claim for testing
* Changing e.g. the MachineType will automic lead to an new Instance

_I want to be able to reach all my_ {{WmsServerHosts}} _via SSH._

We (currently?) need all {{WmsServerHosts}} to be available via SSH, so the Composition has to be extended accordingly.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* There is a field in the XRD that controls the SSH firewall rule for a {{WmsServerHost}}.
* A {{WmsServerHost}} that allows SSH traffic via the above field can be reached via SSH.
items.toString:
_I want to be able to reach all my_ {{WmsServerHosts}} _via SSH._

We (currently?) need all {{WmsServerHosts}} to be available via SSH, so the Composition has to be extended accordingly. After [https://int-log-psise.atlassian.net/browse/DEVOPS-265|https://int-log-psise.atlassian.net/browse/DEVOPS-265|smart-link], there is a network tag {{ssh-server}} that can be used for GCP resources to allow incoming SSH traffic.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* There is a field in the XRD that controls the SSH firewall rule for a {{WmsServerHost}}.
* A {{WmsServerHost}} that allows SSH traffic via the above field can be reached via SSH.

items.fromString:
_As a PSIwms customer-project dev, I want to manage my team’s PSIwms servers as Code so I can adapt them as needed on my own._

In [https://int-log-psise.atlassian.net/browse/DEVOPS-220|https://int-log-psise.atlassian.net/browse/DEVOPS-220|smart-link], a CRD for a WMS server host was deployed.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* The IDP defines one way to declare the WMS server hosts used by a team.
* This way is detailed in the IDP user docs.
* Deploying a {{WmsServerHost}} resource in the {{idp-playground}} results in an {{Instance}} being deployed with the specified preparation to run a PSIwms server on it.
items.toString:
_As a PSIwms customer-project dev, I want to manage my team’s PSIwms servers as Code so I can adapt them as needed on my own._

In [https://int-log-psise.atlassian.net/browse/DEVOPS-220|https://int-log-psise.atlassian.net/browse/DEVOPS-220|smart-link], a CRD for a WMS server host was deployed, but deploying a {{WmsServerHost}} does not result in the deployment of any actual resources yet.

This ticket is about explaining to Crossplane how a {{WmsServerHost}} XRD is composed: it is an {{Instance}} with some init script to install system packages.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* Deploying a {{WmsServerHost}} resource in the {{idp-playground}} results in an {{Instance}} being deployed with the specified preparation to run a PSIwms server on it.

items.fromString:
_As a PSIwms customer-project dev, I want to manage my team’s PSIwms servers as Code so I can adapt them as needed on my own._

We want to create a [Crossplane XRD|https://docs.crossplane.io/latest/concepts/composite-resource-definitions/] called {{WmsServerHost}}.

A PSIwms server host is an {{Instance}} that is already prepared to run the PSIwms server:

* Some required system packages are installed.
* Some environment variables are set.

Parameters for CPU, RAM, etc. can come later; a fixed definition of a PSIwms environment is fine for this story.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* The IDP defines one way to declare the WMS server hosts used by a team.
* This way is detailed in the IDP user docs.
* Deploying a {{WmsServerHost}} resource in the {{idp-playground}} results in an {{Instance}} being deployed with the specified preparation to run a PSIwms server on it.

Our initial users will most probably be colleagues from WMS Ops in Aschaffenburg: they’ll have to use it in order to set up production instances for a handful of customers before May 2025, which is already pretty close.

We need to know about their requirements as soon as possible, and having them interact with the IDP is the most accurate and simple way we know of.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* First contact was established!
* At least one {{Instance}} was created by them.
items.toString:

We need to know about their requirements as soon as possible, and having them interact with the IDP is the most accurate and simple way we know of.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* Mauricio, Matthias and Jan have been asked about relevant future users to get in touch with.
* First contact was established!
* At least one {{Instance}} was created by them.

items.fromString: For some reason, Gitlab CI suddenly started having issues authenticating against our Google Project, see for example [here|https://gitlab.com/psi-software-se/terraform/teams/wms/-/jobs/8568225485]. Because of this, no changes from our repo can be applied to our actual infrastructure.
items.toString:
For some reason, Gitlab CI suddenly started having issues authenticating against our Google Project, see for example [here|https://gitlab.com/psi-software-se/terraform/teams/wms/-/jobs/8568225485]. Because of this, no changes from our repo can be applied to our actual infrastructure.

We have to talk to Central Development about this. They could help us resolve it, any maybe it is even related to recent changes.

items.toString: DNS recfor ArgoCD and website vanished

items.fromString:
For some reason, the DNS entries {{argocd....}} and {{index....}} just disappeared from our DNS zone, see [here|https://console.cloud.google.com/net-services/dns/zones/log/details?invt=AbjZcA&project=psi-de-0-wms-tool-0]. These two entries were successfully managed by Terraform until this morning, but now they’re gone even though there were no changes to that code today.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* DNS records are restored for ArgoCD, Backstage, and the website.
* Our project is configured to log DNS changes.

items.fromString:
When [this commit|https://gitlab.com/psi-software-se/terraform/teams/wms/-/commit/3198edce443375ba369a748b85644e6be88a3410] hit {{main}}, the website [http://index.log.dev.gcp.psi.de/|http://index.log.dev.gcp.psi.de/] should have been updated, because a new version of the website image hit the Artifact Registry with the {{latest}} tag, see [here|https://console.cloud.google.com/artifacts/docker/psi-de-0-wms-tool-0/europe-west3/repo-container/idp-website?inv=1&invt=AbjZLA&project=psi-de-0-wms-tool-0&supportedpurview=project]. ArgoCD doesn’t seem to notice this. The application is configured to pull the image every time a pod is deployed, but we don’t want to delete pods manually to trigger this.

This is related to [https://int-log-psise.atlassian.net/browse/DEVOPS-236|https://int-log-psise.atlassian.net/browse/DEVOPS-236|smart-link], which uses a different version for each image that is built by our pipeline. This ticket is about updating the version referenced in our Helm chart.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* When changes to the website are merged in our repo, those changes are reflected on the actual website after 15 minutes automatically.
* The synchronization mechanism does not negatively affect the uptime of the website.
* Upon changes, the version of our website image in our Helm chart is updated automatically.
items.toString:
When [this commit|https://gitlab.com/psi-software-se/terraform/teams/wms/-/commit/3198edce443375ba369a748b85644e6be88a3410] hit {{main}}, the website [http://index.log.dev.gcp.psi.de/|http://index.log.dev.gcp.psi.de/] should have been updated, because a new version of the website image hit the Artifact Registry with the {{latest}} tag, see [here|https://console.cloud.google.com/artifacts/docker/psi-de-0-wms-tool-0/europe-west3/repo-container/idp-website?inv=1&invt=AbjZLA&project=psi-de-0-wms-tool-0&supportedpurview=project]. ArgoCD doesn’t seem to notice this. The application is configured to pull the image every time a pod is deployed, but we don’t want to delete pods manually to trigger this.

This is related to [https://int-log-psise.atlassian.net/browse/DEVOPS-236|https://int-log-psise.atlassian.net/browse/DEVOPS-236|smart-link], which uses a different version for each image that is built by our pipeline. This ticket is about updating the version referenced in our Helm chart.

*Acceptance Criteria:*

* When changes to the website are merged in our repo, those changes are reflected on the actual website after 15 minutes automatically.
* The synchronization mechanism does not negatively affect the uptime of the website.
* Upon changes, the version of our website image in our Helm chart is updated automatically.
* The pipeline may push a new commit that updates versions of images, but it cannot create loops (building an image leads to pushing a commit with the image’s new version, which triggers an image build, which commits the new version, ……)
